div.head: THE Epistle Dedicatory.
To my Worthy Friends and Patrons at Lockets Ordinary.
div.p: YOU are not to be told, that Poets are sawcy, very sawcy, mighty sawcy, but your (wou'd be) Poet, or Farce Snipper Snapper, such a Promiscuous Riddle me Re, as my self always super-abounding; Therefore do I heartily hope, but more humbly entreat, that with the Piercing Eye of Understanding, and through the Orbicuous Glass of Reason, you will perfectly discern, and then wholly attribute the bold Presumption of this sharp Epistle (as I may justly term it) to my Seeming self as Audacious Ievon the Poet, and not to my Real self as Modest Mr. Ievon the Player. But now I intend to give my self an unwilling Loose to Eloquent Words and Rhetorical Notions (which to Me have always Prompt and Ready bin.) Et ad Vnguem, & ad Pennam, and forthwith cast my self upon the Naked Confines of Mediocrity, and in plain terms come pat and closely to you thus.

You may please to call to mind and well remember that presently after our Catcall Dissolution, which for some time, from our Natural Home, and Provident Stage, dispers'd abroad Us Under-Acting Iews without a Moses to provide our Manna: And after the Prayers (as you may guess) of the many Murmuring Hirelings, for those whose Whistling Breath blew 'em to a more remote and far worse Climate, 'twas then the Needfull I (by dint of Hunger forc'd) wrote (you know full well) such Powerfull Lines to your unmindfull Senate, that had ye not All had Hearts of Stone you wou'd have melted into Retaliating Favours. Your speedy Promises were Great, but your slow Performances (witness ye Unassisting Gods) alas, were Small. Let this my All-Commanding Style, and most Ingenious Piece then now revive and whet your almost blunted Purpose, to a more lively, quick and solid Answer: Let me endear ye all (my Yet but seeming Friends, and promising Patrons only) to a more Ponderous Resolution. and Candid Answer to him that, Gad Judge me, ye know to be
div.signed: Your humble and obedient Servant, THO. JEVON.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
TO THE Grave, Learned, Judicious, and Deliberate.
div.p:
THE Modern Age, and present Representations, unknown to the Antiquated Limits, which in all bounds of Prevalent Atonements, supersede the Equinoctials of Illuminary Spirits, are not in the least captivated with the Decorum of Dress, fortunate and succeeding Action, exhausted Master of Volatory arrided Flashness, that now is not in self, De Re Imaginaria neque supposita de futura, Neither can their profound Precepts, who were known and ador'd as Patriarchs in Natures primitive Sanguinity with collatoral Adherents, with the noise of what was heretofore deliver'd, inculcate Predominancy to the Right Line of Monarchical and Episcopal Adherences. Therefore if in greater and more evident Points the Lawyer can no more be without
his Fee, than the Lord Chancellour his Mace, or a Poet without Errors, (my self alone exempted) why shou'd the Iudgment of a Man that is partially byass'd against the Banditti, rule the Authour's opinion in his own Hemisphere, and discuss at large the Virtues of Jobson's Wife, without the Management of Hobbs his Leviathan? Why shou'd Shakespear, Johnson, Beaumont, Fletcher, that are no way Adequate to the profound Intellects of my present Atonement, be rank'd above the Laborious, tho' dull States-man.
â€” Sed Vastum Vastior Ipse,
Sustulit Aegydes, &c.
Ov. Metam.

Those several Malignant Assertions offer'd, a large and a compendious Resolution ought to be maturely responded, especially, when the Eclypse of Matrimony is subterranially trod down. As to the main Notion of Polygamy absconded under a Cirtoot of Imagination, We take it thus. Alexander was Great and Victorious in his Mediterranean Engagements of Hospitality. To the contrary Julian the Apostate recites his own Benevolencies in semi Octavo of Traditional Vsury: Which plainly denotes the first Egression and the last Denotation. So that if we come to Modern Affairs, you will find that the Masq'd Middle Gallery, being by Command Superiour, brought bare-fac'd to the Prae-existent Spark's construction; more amuses the Sun-shine Planet of his Scarlet Coat, than the beat of an Irish Drum to an East Indie Interloper.
For what says Terence (Paucis te Volo,) which manifestly denotes the condescending temper of the Male, and the diving Aspect of the Female. Now if after so long a Concupiscential Appetite the Novelty of Weeding is to be adjudg'd Ceremonious, I leave to my Lord Chief Justice his Tipstaff to examine, and make all even between the Pope and my Lord Archhishop of Canterbury.

div.head: PROLOGUE, Spoke by Mr. JEVON.
div.l: HOW long is't since you saw I pray,
That strange old fashion'd thing call'd a New Play.
Or how long indeed d'ye think 'twill be,
Before you tast that long'd for Novelty?
You may set your hearts at rest for this Age,
Vnion and Catcaells have quite spoyl'd the Stage.
Time was the Poets cou'd cock, look bigg, and cry,
Damn these saucy Players, let's all agree,
And starve the Rogues, the Times friends turned be,
And I am turn'd Poet, there's Farce d'ye see.
But now to my Geatheration friends,
div.stage: Points to some particular People in the Pit.
div.l: What quick return, or what concise amends.
Have you my ever honour'd ever dear,
Renowned, whistling Patrons made appear
To him that is your servant every where?
My Name's Mr. Jevon, I'm known for and near.
But no more words in so much Company,
Satisfaction I must have and quickly;
Or Gad, Il'e leave off writing directly.
Let me have a pledge of it now y'are here,
Or in your Balls you may forget I fear.
Be favourable to this same piece at hand,
And d'ye hear friends don't, shall I, shall I stand.
If I in Pocket find you dive for Catcall,
Ile let down Curtain, He tell ye that all.
Catcalls well tun'd might do well in Opera's,
They'd serve for Hoboys to fill up a Chorus.
Or in a French Love Song, observe you now,
A Cadmeus Pur Qua, Pur Qua, Meme Vou.
Begar Monsieur it be De pretty Whyne,
Ki La D'ance De Mineway, Oh it be very fine.
Dances you have and various here to Night,
But they are English all, all English quite.
Throughout, English Songs, Farce English too,
That's French Sence,
All Non-sence without any more adoe.
Kickshaws like this serve for a Lenten Dish,
If not for Flesh, pray let it serve for Fish.
And since Pennance at this Time's in fashion,
Come three Days for Mortification.

list.head: MEN,
list.item: SIR Rich. Lovemore. An honest Country Gentleman belov'd for good old Engl. Housekeeping. Mr. Gryffin.
The Ladies Father. Of the old Strain: A Phanatick. [Mr. Norris.
Noddy. A Hypocritical Phanatick Parson, loves to eat and cant, Chaplain to my Lady Lovemore. Mr. Powel.
Iobson. A Psalm-singing Cobler, Tennant and Neighbour to Sir Richard. Mr. Ievon.

list.head: WOMEN,

div.head: THE Devil of a Wife, OR A Comical Transformation.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Jobson the Cobler and Nell his Wife.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: GOOD Husband stay with me to Night and make an end of the Holiday at home.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Peace, peace, and go Spin, for if I want any Thread for my stitching, I will punish you by virtue of my Sovereign Authority.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I warrant you: But you'l go to the Ale-house, spend your Money, and get drunk, and come home like Old Nick, and use one like a Dog.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: How now Brazen-Face do you speak ill of the Government? I am King in my own House, and this is Treason against my Majesty.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I don't understand your stuff, but prithee don't go to the Ale-house.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Well then, I will not go to the Ale-house, I have made an appointment with Sir Richard Lovemore's Butler, and am to be Princely drunk in Punch at the Hall Place; we shall have a Bowl big enough to swim in.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: O Lord Husband, the new Lady they say will not suffer a Stranger to come into her House, she grudges a draught of Small Beer, and several of this Town have come Home with broken Heads from her Ladiships own hands for but smelling Strong Beer in her House.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: A Pox on her for a Fanatick Jade, she has almost distracted the good Knight, but she's abroad feasting with her Relations, and will scarce come home to night, and we are to have much Drink, a Fiddle and Gambals.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: But her Fanatick Parson will disturb you.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: If he does we will toss the Hypocrite in a Blanket, or kick the sanctified Coxcomb to a Jelly.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: O dear Husband let me go with you, wee'l be as merry as the night's long.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Why how now you bold Bettress, what wou'd you be carried to a company of Smooth-faced, Eating, Drinking, Lazy Servingmen; Rogues whose nourishment runs all into Lechery? No, you Jade, I will be no Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I'm sure they wou'd make me welcom, you promised me I shou'd see the House: Sir Richard and the Family have not been there since you married and brought me to Town.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Why thou most audacious Strumpet, darst thou Dispute with me? go home and Spin, or else my Strap will wind about thy Ribs.

sp.speaker: Iobson
sp.l: He that has the best Wife,
She's the Burthen of his Life,
But for her that will Scold and will Quarrel;
Let him cut her short
Of her Meat and her Sport,
And ten times a day hoop her Barrel.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: We poor Women must be Slaves and never have any joy, but you men run and ramble and take your swing.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Why you most Pestilent Baggage will you be hoopt? be gone.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Well I must go.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Here now I think of it, here's six pence for you, get Ale and Apples, stretch and puff thy self up with Lambs Wool, rejoyce and revel by thy self, be drunk and wallow in thy own Stye like a Sow as thou art.

sp.speaker: Iobson
sp.l: He that has a Wife, &c.

div.stage: Enter Sir Richard Lovemore's Butler, Cook, Servingmen, Chamber-maid, and other Women Servants.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I wou'd our blind Minstrel and our dancing Neighbours were here that we may rejoyce a little while, our Termagant Lady is abroad, I have made a most Sovereign Bowl of Punch, and I have a good hoard of Wine and March Beer.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: We had need rejoyce sometimes, but our devilish new Lady will never suffer it when she knows it.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I will maintain it there's more mirth in a Gally than in our Family, our Master Sir Richard is the worthiest Gentleman, nothing but Goodness, Sweetness and Liberality.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: But here's a House turn'd topsie turvy, from Heaven to Hell since her coming hither.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: We are all alike, none of us can scape her rage and fury.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: His former Lady is a Saint in Heaven, and liv'd so on Earth, all Mildness and Gentleness.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Ay, Rest her Soul, she was, but this is inspired with a Legion of Devils, and one plaguy Non-Con Parson worse than all, that makes her lay about her like a Fury.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: I'm sure I always feel her in my Bones, she has an Instrument of Correction made of Whale-bone, and for fear I shou'd forget her good usage, she refreshes my Memory every quarter of an hour: if her Complexion don't please her, or she look yellow in a morning, I'm sure to be laid on and look black and blue for't.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p:
Pox on her, when I carry up her Breakfast I dare not come within reach of her: I have some six broken Heads already. A Lady
quoth a! a Shee-Bear is a civiller Animal: she has robb'd me of my Cunny-Skins, my Kitchin-Stuff, and all my Vails; and brought a damn'd eating godly Fellow with her, that scarce will be content with five Meals a day.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: None of you have been used as I have.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: That's because none of us had a Spade-Beard of a Foot long.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I that have lived five and forty year in the House, and had for twenty years preserv'd a reverent Beard, which made me noted for Wisedom and Discretion through all the Countrey, and she to demolish this poor Beard in an instant.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I beseech you, by what means did she depopulate and waste your Fruitfull Chin?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Why it was ruin'd by Fire, with her own cursed hands she sing'd it off; she said it always smelt of Brewis, and was a Spunge that soak'd up more March Beer in a month than any six the ablest Drunkards in the Hundred cou'd in a year: I sav'd nothing but this same one Sprig that grew upon a Wart, and that by my Naile.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: What pity 'twas to lose such an emblem of Gravity and Wisdome.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Ay, I am become a shame to my Neighbours and dare not show my Chin before 'em: Oh that Beard, that poor Beard, what Authority it had amongst 'em! I had e'ne as live she had gelt me.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: I believe thou had'st, thy Beard was of as much use as any Implement about thee.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Methoughts he look'd like one of the old Patriarchs, in the Arras I have seen an old Eastern King, in a Mortlack hanging very much resembling his Phisnomy.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Oh Mrs. Iane you do my poor Beard too much honour, but farewell dear Beard, I shall never see the like of Thee.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: No, a man may as well hope to have two crops of Oak Timber from the same place, as two such Beards from one Chin in an Age.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Pish, what hurt does the loss of a Beard doe? I was making a Shift for her, and she did not like my Lacing it down; she turns the wrong end of her Fan, strikes me on the Mouth so hard, that she beat out 2 of my Butter Teeth: A shame on her light Fingers.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: She makes the Coachman chain the Footmen to Posts, whip 'em with Dog-whips, and stands by to see the Execution.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Heaven have mercy upon my poor Master, this devilish Termagant Scolding Religious Woman will be the death of him, I never saw a man so alter'd all the days of my Life.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: There's a Perpetual motion in that Tongue of hers, and a damn'd shrill Pipe enough to break the Drum of a man's Ear, I wonder my Master does not kick her and her Parson out of doors.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Her Parson, her Weaver; I believe he never had any Orders, but an inward motion from his Stomach, which inclines him to eat more than a Wolf, and this motion is an inward Call.

sp.speaker: Noddy,
sp.p: (within.) Why, Cook Iohn, Cook, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I'm here, this is his outward Call; now is he almost famisht for his second Afternoons Luncheon.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Why, Iohn, why dost thou neglect me? my Spirits are exhaled, evaporated in Study and Labour; I feel as it were a strange kind of emptifulness, I have not eat this two hours,

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: A Pox on him, set him fast by the Teeth or else hee'l disturb us.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I have a couple of cold Chickens, some Westphalia Bacon, and Christmas Pyes.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: For your Christmas Pyes I defie them, they are abominable Scandalous, and Idolatrous, they savour of Rome, they are so many Fortifications wherein the Whore of Babylon intrenches her self, I will down with them, I will beat them down, my zeal will not suffer such Popery in this House; ye are my Flock, I will see that that Wolf the Whore does not prey upon you and devour you: down, down I say with all her Outworks and High-places, her Superstitious and Idolatrous Structures and Buildings, whether in Minc'd Pyes or otherwise: Your Christmas is an Idol, a very Idol truly, have I not seen him in a Profane Mask, in the Habit of an old Man with a long Spade-beard, and the deluded Rout have worshipped and fallen down before him? your Bagpipes are as Pagan Organs, and your Wassalers lewd and filthy Choristers unto Satan, I may not bear these Rags of the Smock of that Scarlet Whore, my Spirit rises, my Zeal boileth and bubbleth up as it were within me, I am transported with a holy Fury: But do you hear Iohn Cook send up those Chickens.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: What both?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Yea both with some Westphalia Bacon, and do you hear, Iohn? a Tart; and you Mr. Chipp let me have a Bottle of Sack, a Bottle of Ale and a Bottle of March Beer, by help of this refreshment I shall be able to hold out till Supper. Fare ye well till that time.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: What shall we do with this base sniveling Hypocrite? he'll spoil our merry meeting.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: â€› Ill warrant you 'tis but putting out the Candles and we'll make him weary of his Canting, when e're he comes among us.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: So his Provision's gone up.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: He's fast by the teeth for one hour.

div.stage: Enter the Blind Fidler, Jobson and others, Men and Women, and Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: O welcome, welcome, here's to our wish, the Minstrel and our Neighbour! Oh old Acquaintance, Goodman Iobson, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: By my troth I am sharp set towards the Punch, and am now come with a firm Resolution though a Poor Cobler to be as drunk as a Lord, I am a true English heart, and look upon Drunkenness as the best part of the Liberty of the Subject.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Why did you not bring your Wife with you?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Because here are Waggs, young Rogues, and a Man may be a Cuckold before the King's Health can go round.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Iobson we'll have a Catch, strike up Blind Will: Ah Iobson I have heard thee outsing the Lark or Nightingal, thou art heard above all the Church, let there be never so many Voices, thine will still be predominant.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Ay and he holds out the Note of one Verse till the Clark begins to sing the next, he has a pure Wind.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Ay I'm pretty good at a Psalm, I have some reason for it, I have stich'd Soles this thirty years to those Psalms you spake of.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Come, let us fetch out our Bowl of Punch in solemn Procession. Now let us have a Catch in honour of Punch.

div.stage: They bring out the Bowl of Punch singing a Catch, and dancing about it, after which they sit down and drink.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: While you Court a damn'd Vintner for such nasty Liquor,
As worse was ne're swallow'd by dull Countrey Vicar,
And the insolent Rascal will draw what he pleases,
While Boys you may kick 'em when Masters y'intreat 'em,
And from Drawers you up into Aldermen beat 'em;
But they get your Money and you get Diseases.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Stumme Brimstone, Lime, Arsnick, fond Drunkards bewitch,
While the villanous Host not content to be rich,
By Brewing and Poyson sells that by false measure,
No Liquor like Punch gives delight to the Soul,
When we drown all our Cares ith' bottom 'oth' Bowl,
Sincere are our Ioys and immortal our pleasure.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: We brew for our selves and we know each ingredient,
As well for our health as our mirth is expedient,
And who ever drinks Punch shall live merry and long,
It spurs up Iade nature and quickens the blood,
Which if it finds bad it ne're fails to leave good;
And while we drink Punch we shall ever be young.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: And after that I'le bring up the Rear with a swinging Turkey-pye, and a mighty Gammon, besides much Pyes and other Appurtenances belonging to our Office.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Here's our Master's Health in a Bumper. Huzzah.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Our Ladies Confusion in another. Huzzah.
sp.stage: Enter Noddy, knawing the Legg of a Chicken.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: What meaneth this Lewd, Profane, and Babylonish noise, ye Popish Locusts, ye Idolatrous Vipers, this sanctified Place is become a Denn of Wicked ones. Thou Blind misleader of the blind, with thy Lewd Anti-Christian Squeaks, avant, avant, I say Belzebub, avant.

div.stage: He kicks and beats the blind Fidler. They put out the Candles and toss Noddy one from another and beat him.
div.l: Hold, hold, what do ye mean?
Ye Sons of Darkness I defy you,
I can suffer for the truth, I am a witness.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Blind him and gagg him.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Bind him hand and foot.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: I will flee away from farther Persecution, Vipers my Lady will come, she will to your Confusion.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: And as you like this do you come again.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: A Pox on him; to our Business now he is gone. The King and all the Royal Family in a Bumper. Huzzah.

div.stage: [Noddy steals out, they light the Candles.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Are you ready for your Collation?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: No, no, we'll have a bout at Blindmans-buff and a Dance first.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Ay, ay, come I'm old Dogg at that, blind me, perhaps I'm as great a Master at Blindmans-Buff as any one in Europe, no dispraise to any man.

div.stage: [They blind him and dance a dance.
Enter Sir Richard Lovemore and my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O Heaven and Earth! what's here within my House! is Hell broke loose! what Troops of Friends is here, sirrha you impudent Rascal?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p:
My dear be patient 'tis Christmas, a time of Mirth, of Jollity, it has always been the Custome of my House to give my Servants Liberty in this Season, and all my Country Neighbours
used to meet, and with their innocent Sports divert themselves.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy prating, meddle with your own matters, can't I tell how to govern my own house without your putting in an Oar? shall I ask you leave to correct my own Servants?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Good Lady, I thought this had been my House, and those my Servants, and those my Tennants.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Did I bring a Fortune to be thus abused, and snub'd before my Servants, do you call my Authority in Question you inhumane Monster? Look you to your Doggs, your Kites and filthy Cattel, your Faulconers, Huntsmen, and your nasty Grooms abroad, I'll make you know 'tis my Province to govern here, nor will I be controul'd by e're a Hunting, Hauking, unthinking Knight in Christendome.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: A Pox upon all Fools that shall marry for money, I am married to a continual Tempest, Strife and Noise, Canting and Hypocrysie are the daily Portion I have with her; but I'll not bear this long, if I by force oppose her, she falls into fits, and raves worse than any one Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You stinking Scoundrels, and you filthy Jades, I'll teach you to Junkit thus and steal my Provision, I shall be devoured by you.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I thought Madam we might be merry once upon a Holyday.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Holyday, you Popish Curr, is one Day more Holy than another? and if it be you'l be drunk upon't, you Rogue, that by your late Demolish'd Beard, thought your self an Example to the Family, is this your Example?

div.p: Come you Minx, you impudent Flurt are you gigging after an abominable Fiddle? all Dancing is whorish, Huswife.
div.stage: [Jane is sneeking to get away, she catches her and lugs her.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: O Murder, murder, she has pull'd off both my Ears.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Madam, for shame, remember your Sex and Quality.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Remember your own fools head, shall you instruct me?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Madam, I rejoyce that your Ladyship is return'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh good and holy man, how came my Family in my absence thus Debauch'd, Drunken, Profane and Superstitious?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: When my Ears were first offended with these Lewd Noises, I came down grieved in Spirit, and rebuked them, commanding them to surcease from these Superstitious and Idolatrous Rites, which they Sacrifice to that Idol, that beastly Idol, old Father Christmas, and while my Spirit was full of Godly Chastisement, they did extinguish the Lights, surrounded and hemm'd me in, and these Instruments of Satan did buffet me even unto great anguish, and I am sore bruised in Body.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Alack good man! Oh ye Spawn of Belial the Fry of the bottomless Pitt, how now sirrah, who, are you in the Bumble you Buzzard?
sp.stage: She takes the Parson's Cane and beats all the Company, Jobson is stealing by.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: I am an honest Psalm-singing Cobler, Madam; if your Ladyship wou'd go to Church, you wou'd hear me above 'em all there.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll try thy Voice now.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Nounz what a Pox, what a Devil ails you?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O Prosane Wretch, wicked Varlet.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Thou Son of the old Serpent, avant thou Frog of the Lake of Darkness.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Avant thou Coxcombly Son of a Whore of the new Light.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Be gone, Avant, Be gone from within these Walls.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: What will you wrestle a Fall with me? Come on. Take that Lusty Lug you Rogue of a Saint, with a pound of Ear of each side.

div.stage: Jobson gives Noddy a Fall, and lugs him by the Ears.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Impudent Villain, has he not hurt the Good man?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: He hath very much disorder'd my two Ears, and bruised me exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: You deserve it for a medling Coxcomb, go to your Book you ignorant Fop and roade, and rely more upon good Sense, and less upon your new Light.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh wicked vile wretch, was ever poor Lady so miserable so horridly miserable in a Brute to her Husband as I am, I that am so Pious, so Good and Religious a Woman?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: She is an holy, a sanctified Vessel truly.

sp.speaker: Iobson
sp.l: He that has the best Wife,
She's the Burthen of, &c.

div.stage: And some ten times a day hoop her Barrel.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O Rogue, Scoundrel, Villain.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Remember Modesty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Are you gone, Sirrah? I'll rout the rest of you: I'll spoil your squeaking Trebble.

div.stage: She lays about her, they all run, she breaks the blind Fidler's Fiddle about his Head.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: O Murder, murder, I am a dark man, which way shall I get hence? Oh Heaven! She has broken my Fiddle, and undone me, my Wife and Children.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Here Poor Fellow come this way, take your Staff, there, there's money to buy two such Fiddles; go, there's your way.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: Heaven preserve your Worship, bless you sweet Master, here's a Change indeed, little did I think to live to find such Doings at this Hall-Place.

div.stage: Two Wassalers come to the Door singing a Wassal Song.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are very Liberal, must my Estate maintain you in your Profuseness?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Go up to your Closet, Pray and compose your mind.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh wicked Fellow to bid me pray.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p:
A Man cannot be compleatly curs'd without a Wedding, but there is such a thing as separate maintenance and a Joynter-House, which she to morrow shall try, by the help of Heaven, I will no longer bear this nusance in my House. Here, where
are my Servants, what must they be frighted from me? within there, Chipp, come here and see who knocks there.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Within there, where are my Sluts, ye Drabs, ye Queans: Lights there.

div.stage: [Two Maids come sneeking in with Candles.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Sir it is a Doctour that lives ten mile off with his man, he practises Physick, and is an Astronomer and a Cunning-man, your Worship knows him, he can make Almanacks, and help men to their Goods again.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Sir I am benighted, 'tis so dark I cannot see my hand, I cannot possibly reach home, and therefore knowing the Bounty of your Worships Hospitality, I desire the favour to be harbour'd under your Roof this night.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Out of my house you lewd Conjurer, you Witch, you Magician.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Avant thou Instrument of Satan, I defie thee and all thy Works, thou wicked Sorcerer avant.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If you stay in my house, you shall be worse used here, than your Predecessour Dr. Lamb was in the City.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Here's a turn, here's a change, which if I have any Art she shall smart for.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: You see Friend the Case is alter'd with me, I am not Master of my House, but e're to morrow this time I'll be Monarch here: go down the Lane friend, and about half a Quarter of a mile off, you'l see a Coblers house, stay there some little time, and I'll send my Man that shall conduct you to a Tennants house, who shall take care of you.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Thanks good Sir, I'm your humble Servant, but you Noncon with your surious She Disciple there, shall have some proofs of my Magick Art this Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Come Lady you and I must have some Conference.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes I will have Conference and Reformation too in this house, or else I'll turn thee inside outwards.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: My mind misgiveth me, these Varlets have left some good thing in the Bowl there, but hold, is it not a Wassaling Superstitious Spice-Bowl, let me see, hah! it is very comfortable and edifieth, there's a huge Island of Tost, Nutmeg and Sugar, I will attack it, it is Chearing, I have a Paper with some Parmazan in my Pocket, which will eat very well with it, this is also a pleasing Liquor, I will drink plentifully of it and eat Tost exceedingly: ah my Spirits are cheared as it were, and are excited unto Joy and Gladness.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Oh that sweet tooth'd Lickerish Hypocrite who is always eating, and looks as if he had never eaten.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: His meat does himself no more good than his Doctrine does others, stand close, you'l see him devour that Punch-Tost, hee'l never be contented without all in the Bowl.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: It will disguise him most wickedly, and make him as drunk as one of the Profane.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: It doth begin to invade my upper Region, my Pericranium doth seem to be somewhat inclined unto Giddiness, hah the Room appeareth to turn round.

div.stage: [He hekops, belches and sneezes, and is drunk.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: He is overtaken.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: 'Tis a very seasonable time, I'm just going to knock to Supper, and my Lady won't eat without his Grace.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Go quickly, he's in a sweet Pickle for a Grace of a quarter of an hour long as he used to make 'em.

div.stage: [The Cook knocks to supper within, it goes up.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Where am I? am I in the Buttery or my own Closet, a most excellent Spice I'll promise you.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Where are you Mr. Noddy? Supper is on the Table, and my Lady stays for your Grace.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Is it Supper time say you, now I think of it I begin to be hungry.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Pray Sir make hast my Lady stays for you?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: What is the matter with me? I think my Feet are asleep, I cannot use them, my Eyes are somewhat dim too, which is the way?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Ay the Rogue hears my Master intends to turn over a new Leaf, and he has a mind to wind about, but this shan't serve his turn, he's a Fanatick Rogue still.

div.stage: Scene the Cobler's House. Nell, the Dr. and his Man.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Pray Sir mend your Draught if you please, you are very welcome Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Thank you heartily good Woman, come I'll give you some requital, I'll tell you your fortune?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Oh! Pray do Sir, I never had my Fortune told me in my Life.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Let me behold the Lines of your Face?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I'm afraid 'tis none of the cleanest Sir, I have been about dirty work Sir all this day.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Come, 'tis a good Face be not asham'd of it, you shall show it in greater Places suddenly.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Oh dear, I Sir? I shall be asham'd mightily, I want Dacity when I come before great Folks.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You must be confident I charge you, and fear nothing, there is much happiness attends you.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Oh me, this is a rare man Heaven be thanked.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: To morrow before Sun Rise you shall be the happiest Woman in this County.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: How, by to morrow? Alack a day, how can this be?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No more shall you be troubled with a Surly Husband, that shall Rail, call you names and strap you.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Lord how came he to know that? he has a Familiar: indeed my Husband is somewhat rugged, and in his Cupps will beat me but it is not much, He's an honest painfull Man and I let him have his way, pray Sir take the tother Cup of Ale.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Thank you, to morrow you shall be the richest Woman in the Hundred, and ride in your own Coach.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: O Father now you jeer me.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: By Heaven I do not, but mark my words, be confident and bear all out, or worse will follow.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Where is this Queane, here Nell, what a Pox are you drunk with your Lambs-wool?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Oh Husband! here's the rarest man, he has told me my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Pox on you, and has planted my Fortune too, a Lusty pair of horns upon my head, has he?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Thy Wife's a vertuous Woman, and thoul't be happy.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Come out ye hang Doggs, ye Juglers, ye cheating Villayns, must I be Cuckolded by such Rogues as you are, Mackmaticians and Almnack-makers?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Prithee peace Husband, we shall be rich, and have a Coach of our own.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: A Coach! a Cart, a Wheele-Barrow you Jade, by 'th mackin She's drunk, bloody drunk, get you to bed you Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Oh mercy on us, is this a taste of my good Fortune?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: You had better not have touch'd her you surly Rogue.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Out of my House you Rogues, or I'll run my Nall up to the handle in your Buttocks?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Farewell you Paltry Slave?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Get you out you Rogues?

div.stage: [She shuts the door and goes in.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: What? Hoh my Spirits, Nadir and Abishog, hoh!

div.stage: Enter Nadir and Abishog flying down.

sp.speaker: Nadir. Abishog.
sp.p: Here, we're here.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: Praesto, all my Charms attend:
â€› Ere this Night shall have an End,
You shall this Cobler's Wife transform,
And to the Knights the like perform;
This bed the Cobler's Wife I ll charm,
The Knight's into the Cobler's Arm;
Let the Delusion be so strong,
That none shall know the Right from wrong.
The Non-con Parson so affright,
That he may ever Rue this Night;
Scare him from his Little Wits,
And his Hypocritick Fits.

sp.speaker: Nadir. Abishog.
sp.l: All this, this Night we will perform,
In a Whirl-wind, in a Storm.
In Lightning and in Thunder fly,

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: And muster all the Clouds i'th Sky;
Attend me till the Dawn of Day,
And then you may go sport and play.
sp.p: Hold, here comes Sir Richard's Man: he'll guide us to our Lodging, let us meet him to Horse.
sp.stage: Scene Sir Richard's House, the Dining Room, Sir Richard, Mr. Rowland, Mr. Longmore.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Well my dear Friends, though you have found my House in some disorder, I cannot but rejoyce to see you, the sight of Friends will lighten great afflictions.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: Some years have past, since we have been merry together.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: We have not met these five years: Marriage, Travel, Business, and your Retirement, Sir Richard, have thus separated us.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Us that for several years, of pleasant Frolique Youth were ne're asunder.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: I call methinks a pleasant Season back, here's a brimmer to our old Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: About with it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: But now 'tis late, we keep you out of Bed from your new Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: A Wife! Oh Friends take warning, marry not, I say, do not marry.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: Why? you have a handsome Lady and a rich one.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Oh Gentlemen, I would be glad to have the Witch of Endor, were she alive instead of her; I am link'd to an Amozonian Devil, such a Thalestris, such a perpetual Fixen, and a Shrew, such a Tongue, that 'twould be a Blessing to be lodged in London, with a Silver-Smith under me, a Brazier over head, a Trunk-maker and a Peuterer on either side of me, and all of 'em Industrious Rogues to boot; a Blessing I say in Comparison of her continual Clamour, all those Noises in consort are soft and gentle Harmony to her one single Voice.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Methought she looked somewhat proudly, her Countenance between Scorn and Anger.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: She wish'd crooked Pins in every bit of meat you eat, and Poyson in every Glass of Wine you swallow'd.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: Say you so, 'tis time for us to leave you then.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: No, fear not, this Night is the last of her short Reign, I have sent for her Father to dine with me to morrow, and after dinner I will pack her away with her separate maintenance, and then we'll spend the Christmas in Freedom, Mirth and Jollity, and I am overjoy'd you are here to be Witnesses of my Proceedings.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady commanded me to tell you, She'l rout you and your Lewd Companions, if you come not away presently, I hope you'l pardon me.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Tell her I come, I am sent for. But here's the other Brimmer to my Deliverance.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Away with it.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p:
I lay my whole misfortune now before you, I have not onely married an Indefatigable Scold, but a Phanatick into bargain; nay, I have married her Chaplain too, who was, I take a Weaver, and ordain'd himself by virtue of outward Grace and inward Knavery, have a care I warn you of a Bigot or Zealous
Woman, for be she never so wicked, she will be always so full of spiritual Pride, She'll think you a Limb of Satan.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: 'Tis a just observation.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And for a Chaplain, I would as soon have a Russian in my House, for he must Govern or the Wife will Rage.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Right, Then, my Friends, I conjure ye have a care of separate maintenance, a damn'd invention to make Whores and cursed Wives as bad, I wou'd not marry the Queen of Sheba were she alive, upon those Conditions.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: All this daily Experience tells us.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: A Curse of an Owle that must try and would not trust Experience; but at his own cost another Point is, for I am bound in Charity to warn you, have a care of an ill born or ill bred Woman, there is as much in the Straine, as in Horses or Doggs, we all take after our kind.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: You are in the Right of it, I have not heard a better Preaching.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: And for breeding, though almost all Women are Fools, yet those that are well bred, by the help of that will behave themselves with some Discretion and Good manners at least, and now in what a Case am I, that am under all these Curses which I warn you from? how irksome must it be to me, who with my first dear Wife, that St. in Heaven, had all the happiness that man on Earth was capable of?

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: 'Tis hard, but like to be as short.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: One more to the memory of my former Wife, a Brimmer to help to dround my sorrow for this.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Let it go round: we knew her.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: She deserv'd all honour.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now shame upon you and your filthy Companions, I'll make your Glasses and your Bottles fly, and that Lewd Minister of your Debauchery, your Butler I'll rout him, for not bringing me the Key of the Cellar a Rascal.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: Your Pardon, we are going.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Going? yes, to make one another drunk and sott all Night about it, ye may be ashamed ye Beasts, why do I call you Beasts, Beasts, I scorn to be drunk like you.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: This Gentlemen is my sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Gentlemen! your fellow Scotts, your guzling Drunkards, get you to bed ye Spunges?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Light the Gentlemen, your Fires are ready, you see I am under Correction sweet Princess.

div.l: If you in one, would summe up every Curse,
Take such a Spowse for better and for worse.
div.trailer: The End of the first Act.

div.head: ACT the SECOND.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: WEE have had a hard Tug to give these Gentlemen's men their Belly's full.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: But at last we have left 'em quickly up tosome Tune.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: I am Bouzy and right for mischief; let's execute our design upon Non-con.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Have at him, are your Jack-chanes and humming Tops ready?

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: They are, I have 'em here, he must be drunk with a Pox to him, and cou'd not say Grace.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: A Curse on him, he stagger'd against my Side-Table, and brake twenty shillings worth of flint Glasses. And though we all deposed against his Drunkenness, our Pious Lady call'd us perjur'd Rogues, and said he had eaten some thing that did not agree with him.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: And when we cou'd not get him to himself, my Lady said it was an Apoplexy.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Ay, and made me heat a Frying-Pan red hot, to hold over his Pate; from which she had made the hair be shav'd off.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: Nay She has imploy'd all her skill in Physick upon him, She has laid a huge Caustick-Plaister between his Neck and Shoulders to raise blisters, which will make him roar before morning.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: His Head's all raw with the singeing, if he had not begun to roar, I belive She would have Carbonado'd him, for his Apoplectick Drunkenness.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: What Sport it will be when he wakes! he'll wonder what the Devil they have done to him, he'll be plauguy sore.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Now he has almost slept out his first sleep, he'll wake half sober, devilish sick, and in paine, and 'twill be a fit time to begin our Persecution upon him.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I am afraid we shall make him distracted with the Fright.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: If we make him mad he may get some wit by the bargain, he's now so dull a Rogue that any alteration wou'd be for the best.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Come put on the shapes.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: Here, the Dogs will fit me, Iohn Cook shall be the Bear, and you shall represent great Belzebub himself.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Agreed, hang on your Chains, list how the Rogue sports like a Sackbut, let's withdraw into our Tyring-Room, and then Enter.

div.stage: The Scene opens and discovers Noddy in Bed, and they Enter.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Mr. Chip, why Butler Chip, I say some small Beer, give me an Ocean of small Beer, I will swim in small Beer.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: He's between sleeping and waking, now to our Work.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Mercy on me where have I been? I am all on Fire, and my head all burnt, is the Bed or the Room on Fire? fire, fire, fire, hah Heaven what Noise is that! hah it is Satan verily, what Friends are those in Chains? Oh Faith, Faith! where art thou? I am frail, frail, even as one of the They set the humming Tops a going, then rattle their Chains. wicked. Oh! mercy, mercy, how, I dissolve, who are ye, in the Name of Heaven? speak, what will they do? will they fetch me from hence? Oh Satan! sweet Satan, dear Satan, spare me, thou mistakest me, tempt me not, I am not Righteous, I am wicked, yea even as one of the Profane. I am an Hypocrite truly, a zealous Hypocrite verily: Oh spare me, oh! oh! sweet Satan, dear Satan spare me.
sp.stage: They pull all the Clothes off the Bed.
[He holds 'em with all his strength and roars.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: This is enough in the dark, now let him behold ye?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p:
Oh, oh, I conceive there is a Light now in the Room, let me see if I dare open my Eyes: He brings in a Light. Oh Heaven what Friend is this comes to me? it is like a Dog, oh! oh! I conjure thee, Friend! say The Serving Man in his Dogs shape creeps to the Bed. what thou art; in the Name of Heaven, if thou beest a Dog speak, oh, oh, what's here a Bear? avant, avant, O Good Satan forbear, oh what's
here the Chief Devil! I dare not see any more, oh sweet Belzebub, spare me, mercy good Satan.

div.stage: The Cook lyes down on the Bed like a Beare, Noddy roares yet lowder, and shrinks under the Clothes and speaks.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Art thou a true sear'd Hypocrite?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Yea I am, I am.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Falsely zealous, and truly seditious?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Oh, oh, I, I am Sir.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Most immoderately given to thy Gut?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Yes, yes, my great delight is in Creature comforts.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: The chief motive to thy Zeal, those Creature comforts, thou get'st by thy Hypocroisie.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Oh, oh! yes verily.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: By this thou hast committed Carnality with Elders Wives and Daughters; and hast been much given to Concupiscence.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: 'Tis true, most exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: You use not Copulation with the wicked, for fear of Scandal?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: No, I engender onely with the Righteous: Good Sir, have done, I am half dissolv'd.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: By this thou get'st thy self made Executor and Trustee.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Oh yes, it is the chief end of my Profession to prey on Orphans.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Oh Rogue! ha what a dreadfull Thunder-Clap was that.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: What a storm is this arising?

div.stage: [Serv, and Cook come from the Bed.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Gods body what a Clap was there, it shook the House.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: Come let us be gone, we have tormented him enough.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: No, no, this storm will help us better to affright him.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: The Rogue shall no longer rail at auricular Confession, who, has confessed as he thinks to the Devil.

div.stage: Nadir rises with a great Thunder-Clap and Appeareth to them.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Oh! I am almost dead, sure the Fiends are gone, and have carried this end of the Building with them at that last Clap.

div.stage: [He is preparing some Toads on a plate.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Come, come 'tother bout.

sp.speaker: Nadir.
sp.p: Ay, come, come.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Hah Tom! what's this? we are four now.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: Why Ned? we were but three, ha! one, two, three, four?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Ha Iohn! what's the meaning of this? who is this?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Nay, what a Pox know I? I am sure we were but three, we are increased one in Number.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Foh, what a stink of Brimstone's here.
sp.stage: The Spirit is placing a Toad upon a plate, the Spirit goes to Noddy, he eats a Toad, and on his Fork presents Noddy with another.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Let me see, what is he a doing?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: There is silence, now let me peep out. Oh Heaven!

sp.speaker: Nadir.
sp.p: Here Parson eat this Toad, here will you eat this Toad?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Oh Heaven what's this! my Hair begins to stand on End.

sp.speaker: Nadir.
sp.p: Eat this Toad I say.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Oh, no good Satan, I hate a Toad, it is too like Fish, and I cou'd never endure Fish, because the Papists eat so much.

sp.speaker: Nadir.
sp.p: Who will eat a Toad?
sp.stage: Nadir turns him to the Company, and Fire flashes about him

sp.speaker: Butler. Cook. Serv. Man.
sp.p: Oh the Devil, the Devil, oh! oh!

div.stage: They run roaring out, and Noddy roars, the Scene shuts upon the Bed.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: The Devil, the Devil.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: If ever I fright any Body again, may I suffer the Strappado.

div.stage: Enter Sir Richard with a Candle and his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: What noises are these? here are Thieves in my House; what, ho where are my Servants?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Here Sir, we are got up, there have been most horrible Disturbances in the Parson's Chamber, he roars like a furious Bull with the Dog about him, listen.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: The Devil, the Devil: Murder, help, help.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Hang him the Rogue's drunk still, is it he that has disturb'd the House?

div.stage: Noddy comes running in roaring with a Blanket about him.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Oh the Devil, the Devil, avoid thou Tempter.

div.stage: Enter hastily Rowland and Longmore, with their Swords drawn with a light.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: What is the matter here?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Oh Sir Richard, we have been so disturb'd with Noises, we thought some Rogues had got into your House, and were committing a Robbery.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: It's nothing but a Drunken Zealot, that has been troublesome in his Cupps, and he has disturb'd the House.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Drunk! I defy thee and all thy works.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Ha, what Apparition is that?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Apparition, whose, where?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: I shall soon make your Apparition vanish.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: I have seen a Vision this Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: What of Malt and Hops, Punch and Stratsbury Brandy, or a Fools-head in a Looking-glass? take him and lock him into his Chambers.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Oh for Heaven's sake! 'tis haunted with Devils, I have been tormented all Night: They have laid a Plaister of melted Btimstone upon my Shoulders, and singed my Head with sulphurous Flames, oh the Devil, the Devil!

div.stage: [They hurry him off, and lock him up.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: You shall disturb the House no more to Night: Gentlemen, I am sorry that this Phanatick Preacher should disturb you, he was drunk last Night and fancies he's haunted with Devils, he's nothing but frighted with the Thunder and Lightning, at this time of the Winter.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: Which has been the strangest I ever heard, I thought the House had fallen down, or at least part of it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Such Thunder in this Winter Season is prodigious, methinks it shou'd fright the Women out of their Wits.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: I cou'd not wake my sweet Lady, She lay as if She were dead, I believe it is her property to be silent in a storm, and ever tempestuous in a Calm.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: See what's a Clock by the Pendulum.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: 'Tis within less than half an hour of five.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: 'Tis almost time to think of hunting: you told us we should see your Harriers run.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Let's to our Chambers and rest an hour or two; we have Game just by.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: With all our Hearts.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Bid the Grooms be ready, Butler, Do you call us; and Cook be ready with a Breakfast, come Gentlemen our way is the same.

sp.speaker: Nadir.
sp.l: Well met, 'tis time we now be gone,
Already all our Work is done;
The Transformation's wrought so sure,
The Doctour's time it shall endure.
The Lady's in the Cobler's Hutt,
The Cobler's Wife to'th Knight is put;
And we defie the sharpest Sight,
E're to distinguish which is Right.

div.stage: Scene the Cobler's House, Jobson in his Stall, his Bed in sight of it.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: What has the Devil been abroad to Night? I never heard such Thunder-Claps and such a Storm, I thought my little House wou'd have flown away. But now all is clear, and 'tis a fine Star-light Morning. Come I'll to work: Winters Thunder is Summers wonder.

lg.l: In Bath a wanton Wife did dwell,
As Chaucer be did write;
Who wantonly did spend her Days
In many a fond Delight.
Vpon a time sore Sick she was,
And at the length did Dye:
Her Soul at last at Heavens Gate
Did knock most mightily.
Then down came Adam to the Gate,
Who knocketh there quoth he?
I am the Wife of Bath she said,
Who fain wou'd come to thee.
Thou art a Sinner Adam said,
And here no place can'st have:
Alack for you good Sir she said,
Go Gipp you doating Knave.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How now? what impudent Ballad-singing Rogue's that, that dare wake me out of my sleep? I'll have thee flead thou Rascall.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Why? what a Pox, does this Jade talk in her sleep, or is she drunk still.

lg.l: I will come In in spite, she said,
Of all such Churls as thee:
Thou art the cause of all our Pain,
Our Woe and Misery.
Thou first brokest the Commandements,
In pleasure of thy Wife.
When Adam heard her tell this Tale,
He ran away for Life.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why Villain, Rascall, Screech-Owle; a worse Noise than a Dog hung in the Pales, or a Hog in a great Wind. Here where are my Servants? come and hamstring the Rogue.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Why, how now you saucy Jade, you confounded Quean, you must be drunk with Conjurers, you shall have mony for Lambs-wool, you whoreson Drab.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Death! what Dog is this? where's my Bell? I can't find it to ring, where's my Servants? I'll toss the Dog in a Blanket.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: She is asleep sure, and all this is a Dream; the Conjurer told her she shou'd keep a Coach, and she is dreaming of her Equipage, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why Husband, Sir Richard do you hear this Insolence?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Husband! Sir Richard! what a Pox has she Knighted me? my Name is Zekel too, here's a jest indeed!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hah he's gone, he's not i'th Bed, Oh Heaven! where am I? foh, what favour is this in my Nostrils! here are stinking Lether Breeches, and a Lether Apron, here are Canvas Sheets and filthy ragged Curtins, a Beastly Rug and Flock-Bed: am I awake? or is all this Dream? what Rogue is that? Sirrah! where am I? who brought me hither? Rogue! what Rascall are you?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: This is most amazing, I never heard such words from her, so God save me, if I take my strap, I'll make you know your Husband, and teach you a little better manners, you saucy Drab.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh astonishing impudence! you my Husband! I'll have you hang'd you Rogue, I'm a Lady sirrah, let me know who gave me a sleeping Potion, and convey'd me hither.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: A Sleeping Potion, a Pox on you, you drunken Jade, you had a sleeping Potion, has not your Lambs-wool done working yet?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where am I? where has my damn'd villanous Husband put me? why, Iane, Lettis, where are my Queans?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what does she call her Maids? the Conjurers have not onely made her drunk, but mad too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He talks of Conjurers, sure I am bewitch'd, ha! what Cloaths are here? here's a Linsey-woolsey Gown, a Callicoe Hood, and a Red-Bays Petticoat, and Shoes with Hobnails, I'm remov'd out of my own House by Witchcraft, what shall I do, or what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Heark the Hunters and the merry Horns abroad, why Nell you lazy Jade! 'tis Break of Day, come to work, come, come and spin you Drab, or I'll swinge your lazy Hide for you; Pox on you must I be working two hours before you in a Morning?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why Sirrah, you impudent Villain, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Iohson.
sp.p: Know you, yes, and will make you know me before I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am Sir Richard Lovemore's Lady, how came I here?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Sir Richard Lovemore's Lady, no not so bad yet, She's a damn'd stingy Phanatick Whore, and plagues every one that comes near her, the whole Country curses her.
sp.stage: [She flings Bed-staffs and Lumber at his Head.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay then I'll hold no longer, you Rogue, you insolent Villain have at you.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: This is more than e're I saw by her, She's mad sure, I never had an ill word from her before, come Strap I'll try your mettle; I'll fetch you out of your Drunken Fitts you maukin, come, come on Huswife.
sp.stage: [He straps her, she flys at his throat, they fight.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh murder, murder! I'll pull you throat out, I'll tear your Eyes out, I'm a Lady sirrah, Sir Richard Lovemore will hang you for this.

sp.speaker: Countryman.
sp.p: Why Neighbour Iobson, what is the matter? I was going to fodder my Cattle, and hear murder cry'd here.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh Fellow, do you know Sir Richard Lovemore?

sp.speaker: Countrym.
sp.p: Ay marry do I well enough, he's my Landlord, he's as honest a Gentleman as any is in fourty mile o'his head.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Prithee Neighbour don't mind her, She was drunk yesterday with Conjurers, She's mad still, and I can't get her up to her Spinning-work.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh help me, I'm Sir Richard Lovemore's Lady, convey'd hither I know not how, to be tormented and lamed by this outragious Villain.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Did not I tell you she was mad, come out you Jade, I'll fetch you to your Spindle.

sp.speaker: Countrym.
sp.p: Hold you Neighbour, this is a pretty Whirlegig? I know my Lady right well and Goody Iobson too, ah Goody Iobson I'm sorry to see this, you are mad indeed, my Lady Quo she.

div.stage: [He takes the Candle and looks on her.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: What a Pox, do you think I don't know my own Wife? that mole under her left Eye?

sp.speaker: Countrym.
sp.p: A Lady? no Neighbour Iobson, thou'rt ten times a better Woman no Dispraise to her, She's the hearteats Jade that e're came i'th Parish, the whole Country curses her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh he has bruised me, and larned me, and I am almost dead with the stench of this filthy place, either I am removed by Enchantment, or they have given me Opium, and in a dead sleep they have brought me hither, are you in earnest? look on me, do you not know my Lady Lovemore? I'll give you a hundred pound and carry me home.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Why you mad Beast, you my Lady Lovemore? A Pox on her, I know her well enough, she gave me three or four damn'd Blows of the Pate last Night, in her own House.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I did so, I remember you now, I did give you those Blows on the pate, in my House last Night.

sp.speaker: Countrym.
sp.p: Why Goody Iobson, why do you think I'm blind? I do not know my Lady? a plaguy Quean, why all the Countrey rings of her.

div.stage: She falls upon the Countrey Fellow, and beats him out of Doors, he runs out crying help, help.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This is a Conspiracy of Rogues.

sp.speaker: Countrym.
sp.p: Help, help, if She be not my Lady, she has learnt of my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Is this the Rogue my Husbands revenge upon me? here's Clothes, here's filthy Rags; ob foh! oh miserable Woman! I shall be deliver'd and make 'em rue for it.

div.stage: Enter Jobson with a Rock and Spindle.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Come, come you Quean, I'll make you leave your fooling, come to your Spindle, or else I'll lamb your Hide, you were ne're lamb'd so since you were an Inch long. Take it up you Jade.

div.stage: [She flings it down, he straps her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, hold, what shall I do? I can't spin.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Oh! I thought I should bring you to your self to work, I'll into my Stall, 'tis broad day now, why, when you awkard Jade? I think her Brains are turn'd, She has forgot to spin.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I know this place, I'll try my Feet, I'll run into the Town, some body will succour me there sure.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: What does the Jade run for't? I'll after her.

div.stage: The Scene changes to Sir Richard Lovemore's House, the Bed-Chamber, Nell, Jobson in Bed.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: What Heavenly dreams I have had this Night? methought I was in Paradise, upon a Bed of Roses, and of Violets, and the sweetest Husband by my side; sure it was a Dream, Ha! where am I now? bless us! what sweets are these about me? no Garden in the Spring can equal them, not Buds of Roses with the Dew upon them, am I upon a Bed? the Sheets are Sarcenet sure; no Linnen ever was so fine, what a gay silken Robe have I gotten? Oh Heaven I dream! I dream nothing but Point and Lace, and Gold, and Fringe. Oh let me never wake! nothing but Gold, fine Works and Carving: oh Father what a Glass is there! there's a sumptuous Carpet upon the Table and silver Plate, sure I dy'd to night in my sleep, and am gone to Heaven and this is it!

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Now must I go to be call'd Whore or Jade, and fifty other Names, I must wake an alarm that will not lye still till Midnight at the soonest, Madam. Madam.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Lord who this, what sayst thou sweet Heart?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Sweet heart, O Lord Sweet heart! the best Names I have had these twelve Months from her, have been Whore or Jade: Madam, what Gown and what Ruffles, will your Ladyship please to weare to Day?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Oh Lord what does she mean? Ladyship, Gown and Ruffles, sure I am awake now, I remember the Cunningman!

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Say you Madam?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: The same I did yesterday Child.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Mercy upon me! Child! here's a Miracle!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Is my Lady awake, and have you had e'rea slipper or a shoe flung at your Head yet?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Oh no, I am overjoy'd, she's in the kindest humour, nothing but Love and Sweetness, go to the Bed and speak to her now, now is your time.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: You laugh at me, now is your time says she, what to have an Eye beaten out or another Tooth? Madam.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: What say'st thou Girl? Father, what wou'd she have?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: What work will your Ladyship have me do to day? shall I work Plain-work, or go on my Parchment?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Work say'st thou, why? 'tis holiday Child, no work to Day.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Oh mercy, am I or she awake! or do we both dream?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Did not I tell you?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Here's a blest Change!

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: If it continues we are all made, we shall be a happy Family.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Footboy.
sp.p: Now shall I be condemn'd to the Dog-whip, instead of a Breakfast.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Some Billets for your Ladiships fire?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: That's a good Boy.

sp.speaker: Footboy.
sp.p: O Lord! O Lord, is that my Lady?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Go Sir, she's in rare humour.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Prithee Sweetheart give me my things, I'll rise, I can't abide to lie in Bed.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Have I my sences or not, Good Lack?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: This Cunning-man is a rare Man: he said I must bear it out, I'm amazed? I know not what to doe.

div.stage: [Jane gives her a Rich Morning Gown.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Here's your Ladiships Morning Gown.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Where are my Eyes? they are Dazled, this is a Robe fit for an Angel to wear. Bless me, I shall not know my self.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Your Ladiships Chocolate's ready.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Mercy on me what's that? 'tis some Garment sure! well put it on then Sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Put it on Madam, I have taken it off, 'tis ready to Drink.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Drink say's she, I mean, put it by, I don't care for Drinking.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Now go I like a Beare to the stake, to know what her Scurvy Ladiship will have for Breakfast, how many Rascally names shall I be call'd!

sp.speaker: Footboy.
sp.p: You are mistaken, there never was such a change, she's nothing but Goodness, you'l be overjoy'd to hear her.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: You arch Dog! I'll lug you by the Ears Sirrah, if you play the Rogue with me.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Oh! Iohn Cook you'l be out of your wits to see this change, oh! she's the sweetest Lady.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: What the Devil are they all mad!

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Madam, here's the Cook come to know what your Ladiship will please to have for Breakfast.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Oh Lord there's a fine Cook: He looks like one of your Gentlefolks. (Aside.) I am very hungry indeed, honest Man, pray get me a Rashar upon the Coals and a peice of one Milk Cheese, and some White-bread.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Here's Humility! what a Conversion's here?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Hey what's to doe here! what the Devil's the matter! my Head turns round: where am I? honest Man! I look'd for Rogue or Rascal at the best.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Oh Madam that will lye heavy upon your Ladiship's Stomach: hee'l get you some rare dainty Dish immediately.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Doe then e'ne what twoo't good Mr. Cook.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Good Lord! good Mr. Cook! Ohcis a sweet Lady. [Aside. And by my troth I will Madam presently. I'm overjoy'd! methinks I cou'd leap out of my Skin.
Chip, kiss me, prithee kiss me I say: I'm out of my Wits. We have the rarest Lady, the sweetest Lady that ever Men serv'd: go and be astonisht as I am.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: You shamming Rogue, I think you are out of your Wits indeed; what the Devil do's he mean? the Maid looks merrily too.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Chip the Butler is come Madam to know what your Ladiship will please to drink: Come near Mr. Chip. You'l be amazed.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Good Mr. Chip, let me have some good Small Beer when my Breakfast comes up.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Mr. Chip! Mr. Chip! I shall be turn'd into a Stone with amazement. Madam, wou'd not your Ladiship please to have a Glass of Frontinuque or Lachrimoe?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Oh me, what hard Names are these! I must not betray my self. [Aside.] Yes if you will Mr. Butler.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Heaven and Earth, I'm amaz'd! here will be Joy! go get you in and be happy as I am. Joy, Joy.

sp.speaker: Coachm.
sp.p: The Cook has been bantring I do know not how long Do the Butler banter too?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Madam the Coachman is at the Door.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Come in good Coachman.

sp.speaker: Coachm.
sp.p: Will your Ladyship please to take the Air to day? if so, which will you have the Coach or the Chariot?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Thank you, which you think convenient.

sp.speaker: Coachm.
sp.p: O Heaven! the Sky will fall, what's this?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Sure I cannot be awake, how overjoy'd they all seem to wait on me, Oh notable Cunning man, I'm the happiest Woman, I grow giddy with my happiness, I'll retire and give Heaven thanks for this, (aside.) where is the Common-prayer Book?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Common-Prayer Book! here's a turn, what will Non-con say? your Ladyship has none, but here's my Master's.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Thank you Sweet heart.

div.stage: Enter Sir Richard and his two Friends from hunting.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: How do you like this Gentlemen? we have had a smart turn or two.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: I never follow'd fleeter Dogs that had any Noses.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I hate your meer fleet Hounds, that kill presently in view, it is as bad as coursing.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Methinks there's Pleasure to see 'em hit it off at a fault, as well as there is in a hard riding.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And to see the Doubles, and Shifts an old Hare will make for her Life, faith beyond a Fox.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: I spare my Horses to day which made me come home so soon, but to morrow you shall try my Fox-hounds, and then Gentlemen I will lead you a dance.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Sir, here's the rarest News.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: There never was the like, Sir you'l be overjoy'd and amazed.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: What are ye mad? what's the matter with you?

div.stage: Enter the Coachman, and three or four Servants more jumping in.

sp.speaker: Coachm.
sp.p: How now? what's the matter? here's a new Face in my Family, what all joy and mirth, what does it mean, or is it a Christmass Gambal?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Oh Sir the Family is turn'd topsie turvy, we are almost distracted, we are the happiest People.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: I cannot contain my self, my self, my Lady, Sir my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: what is she dead?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Dead! no Heaven forfend, she's the best Lady, the swetest Lady.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Oh the dearest, kindest Lady, you are the happiest man Sir living.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Never was such a change, such a miracle, why, all the House will lay down their Lives for her.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: She has oblig'd us all the kindliest and the sweetliest, we'll live and dye with her.

sp.speaker: All the Servants Speak together.
sp.p: Ay, all, all of us, long live her Ladyship, God bless her Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Oh She's the best Lady in the World, I cou'd kiss the Ground she goes on.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I cou'd lick the Dirt of her Shoes, she's the sweetest, gentliest natur'd Lady breathing.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Why? give me Breath a little, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: 'Tis true, 'tis true Sir, go into her your self, and be witness of her strange change, none but Heaven cou'd work such a miracle.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: This is most astonishing, Gentlemen you see how I am surprized, if you please to dress, I'll in and see the meaning of this Wonder, I'm impatient till I go in.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Sir you may put off your Boots and dress first, She's at Prayers with the Common-Prayer Book in her Closet, and will be private for half an hour.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: How, Common-Prayer Book? new Prodygies! what miraculous Power has been here at work? my Friends, if this be true I shall rejoyce indeed.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: True, ay 'tis true enough, long live Sir Richard and his Lady, Heaven bless 'em both, Huzah, Huzah.

div.trailer: The End of the second Act.

div.head: ACT the THIRD.

sp.speaker: NELL
sp.p: I well remember the Cunning-man warned me to bear all out with Confidence, or worse he said wou'd follow, I am ashamed and know not what to doe with all this Ceremony; I am amazed, and out of my Senses, I look'd i'th Glass, and saw a gay fine thing I knew not, methought my Face was not at all like that I have seen at Home, in a peice of a Looking Glass fastned upon the Cupboard. But great Ladies they say have flattering Glasses, that show them far unlike themselves, whilst Poor-folks Glasses show e'm as they are.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Oh Madam, Here's my Master now return'd from Hunting.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! this goodly Gentleman my Husband?

sp.speaker: Sir. Richard.
sp.p: My Dear; I am extreamly pleased to see my Family thus transform'd to all the joy imaginable, which as they tell me, you have created in them.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Sir I shall be always overjoy'd, at what gives you delight, and shall be ever glad, if I can please your Family.

sp.speaker: Sir. Richard.
sp.p: Oh Divine Softness! this Gentleness of thine transports me.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Alas Sir what am I? I am ashamed of my own meanness, I shall be glad to be a Fellow Servant here, you are Lord of all Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Dear Creature, if thou continuest thus, I had rather be Lord of thee than of the Indies.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: You make me Blush Sir; I hope I shall have Grace never to be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Sir. Richard.
sp.p: I am astonish'd, can this be Real?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: All that's good above can witness for me: I am in earnest.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Rise sweetest Creature, what has wrought this admirable change?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Alas! I never did offend you nor any of them.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: [Aside.] What does she mean? I have not known a Calm within my House these six Weeks: but Yesternight you triumph'd over me, and all my Family, was not that offence?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: It was not I; I sure was not my self then, indeed, I find my self so much changed, I scarce know who I am?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: It is a blessed change.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: It is so, I have that pleasure in my mind; that every thing I see ravishes me with joy, such a sweet House, such brave Furniture, such ready loving Servants, and so noble, so sweet a Lord and Master: Oh Father! I know not where I am methinks!

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Heaven be thanked for this: I wou'd not lose this Dear, this Blessed Creature, for all the Wealth and Power that King's can boast off.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: 'Tis sure Heaven's doing: and I can never have another mind, 'tis wondrous that I ever had methinks.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: And I am confirm'd: Joy! Joy! Oh heart make room for Joy! it will overwhelm you else, upon my knees I kiss this dear, dear hand: Thou art so rare a Creature, I shall worship thee.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Nay hold Sir! pray Sir! what doe you doe? Indeed you make me cry, I am so ashamed, oh Father! so brave a Gentleman to kneel to me? 'tis My duty to doe that.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Hold heart, I say contain thy self, where are my Friends, my Servants, call e'm all, and let e'm be witnesses of my happiness.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: O Lord! how shall I behave my self before these Gentlefolks.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: And wilt thou never childe, nor quarrel with me more, and show thy fury amongst my Servants?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I'll cut my Tongue out first, oh Lord I chidel.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: I have one thing more, wilt thou go to Church with me, and leave the sniveling Conventicle?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Yes surely Sir, I'll do what e're you please, I'll have nothing to doe with Fanaticks, they are a Melancholy ill condition'd People.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Sure t'was an Angel spoke in thee, thou art the best of all thy Sex, I hope thou art convinc'd that the Phanatick Chaplain was drunk last night; woud'st thou let me discard him, there wants nothing then to compleat my happiness.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Yes, Heaven forbid else: what shall I disobey my Lord and Master?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Let me embrace my Dear, my Love, and prithee seal this promise with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Oh rare sweet man! he smells all over like a Nosegay, Heaven preserve my wits.

div.stage: Enter Rowland, Longmore, and all the Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Gentlemen, behold this day, here stands the hapstiest man that the sun shines on, I am transported beyond my senses: I hear proclaim a Jubile to all my Family these three months: Summon in all the Countrey, I'll keep open house, send for my Fidlers, Hoboys, Trumpets, and all Instruments of joy: let all the Bells in the Hundred Ring, let the Seeples Rock, and let the Ringers Drink enough: here stands the best of Women and of Wives, the kindest and the gentlest Mistress to her Servants: and she that has given me all this happiness.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Lord Sir, you put me out of countenance, I blush, I'm sorry that I ever angred any of you, indeed i'll do you all the good I can, I shou'd be to blame else.

sp.speaker: All the Servants cry.
sp.p: God bless my Lady, long live her Ladiship, we'll live and dye with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: My Dear you did affront these Gentlemen last night, speak to e'm.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Indeed, I was not my self, i'm sorry that I was uncivil, I hope in time to mend.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: We are your Ladiships humble Servants, and largely must partake of the great joy, which now possesses all the Family.

sp.speaker: Longm.
sp.p: Joy, Joy, to both the Bridegroom and the Bride; 'tis a new Wedding.

sp.speaker: Sir. Richard.
sp.p: 'Tis true; some three months since, I did espouse her Body, this day I'm married to her mind, this is a perfect Wedding: go send for all my Tenants, there shall be nought but Feasts and Revels here.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: This will be a brave time, how I shall joy to see it.

div.stage: [A flourish of Musick. Without enter Servingman.

sp.speaker: Serv. Man.
sp.p: Your Fidlers were going by, having heard that my Lady wou'd not allow of Musick, but I call'd e'm in.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: You did well; my Dear, do you not love Musick?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Oh! I love nothing better.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: That's my joy, my life; call in my Musick: Gentlemen, i'll make e'm sing a very unfashionable song to you, in the praise of marriage, a peice of my own Poetry in my last Wives time.
sp.stage: [They come in and sing the Song.

lg.l: Let the vain Spark consume his store,
In keeping an expensive Whore,
For others to employ.
For all those snares, and baits he pays,
Which she for other Gallants lays,
And he must least enjoy.
Keep Whores then as perfumes you wear;
Of which your selves have the least share:
Of other's claps partake.
Your Bodies bring to'th Surgeons hands,
And to the Scriveners all your Lands:
And give her your last Stake.
While with reason we bless the Fate,
That brings us to the Marriage State,
The only happy Life.
The chief enjoyment in a King,
No Wealth, no Power, such joy can bring;
As does a Wife, a tender Wife.
There can be no true Friend beside,
So oft does interest divide;
But they are so conjoyn'd.
By this most Sacred Rite are grown,
That they are not one flesh alone,
But they are both one Mind.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Sir, here are some Countrey Neighbours hearing of the happy conversion, desire to dance before you.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Let them come in.

div.stage: Enter Noddy wrapt up in his Night Cap.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: What meaneth this lewd noise; this most prophane abominable Jigging? Lady I must rebuke thee, in pure zeal, I must rebuke thee, I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Thou insolent fool be silent, I will have no Phanaticks, no Law-Breakers within my Walls, especially no Hypocrites, you were drunk last night you Swine.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: I defie thy words, it was a fit, I was taken with a fit, a greivous fit: Lady, what say you, are you become like one of the wicked ones?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I will obey my Lord and Master, his will is mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Retire to your Chamber, you shall not be seen this day, to morrow I will tell you more of my mind.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: What's this, she is not as she was; Iampridem mulieri ne credas ne mortuoe quidem; I may not go, I will not retire, my Zeal telleth me, I must rebuke thee, and I will thunder in thine Ears.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Turn him out.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: I may not go, I say I will not retire, my Zeal transporteth me, I am become furious.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Father you are welcome, doubly welcome; I sent for you upon another occasion than I now find: Heaven has ordered things another way, we are all transported with excess of joy, my Dear salute your Father.

sp.speaker: Nell.
