sp.p: Good Heaven! my Father; what means this sure? I shall be distracted, but I must bear it out.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: What meaneth this, 'tis superstitious, and favours of Idolatry?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing but her great Humility.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: I like it not.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I shall endeavour then to please you Sir.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: 'Tis well, I am glad to see you and my Son-in-Law well; but what's the cause of this unwonted joy of this transport?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: The Cook has knocked to Dinner: let's in, you there shall have a full account, and be a joyfull witness of our Happiness.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Was ever Woman yet so miserable? I cannot make one in the Village yet acknowledge me, they sure are all of the Conspiracy, this wicked Husband of mine has laid a Develish Plot against me, I for the present must submit that I may get an opportunity into my hands for my Design, here comes a Rogue I will have strangled, but now I yield.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Come on Nell, art come to thy self yet?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay I thank you, I wonder what I ailed, this Cunning-man put Powder in my Drink most certainly.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Powder! the Brewer put good store of powder of malt in it that's all, Powder Quo ' she, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I never was so days of my Life.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Was so, no, nor I hope ner'e will be so again, to put me to the trouble of strapping you so Devilishly.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll have that Right hand cut off, for that you were unmercifull to bruise me so.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Why? Faith I'm sorry for it, but it did you a great deal of good tho, why? you wou'd have been mad and call'd your self my Lady Lovemore till this time else, why come, why don't you Spin?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I can't you have bruised my Arms so, when they are well I'll work hard.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: That's my good Girl, I'll buy some Plums to make thee a minc'd Pye, come let's be friends, faith kiss and friends.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh cursed impudent Rascal, what does he say?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Nay, prithee now, faith I won't strap thee so no more.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I must stay till this be well, before I forget it.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Ounz if you go to that, I will kiss you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh soh, how the Beast stinks of Cheese, Leather-apron, Pitch, Greace, foul Linnen and old Shoes.

div.stage: Enter the Country Fellow with two or three more with him.

sp.speaker: C. Fellow.
sp.p: Why Neighbour Iobson? Why don't you put on your Bond, and go to the Hall-place?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: C. Fellow.
sp.p: Matter! why? there's such a change, they are all out of their Wits, there's open House to be kept there till Candlemas, all the Tennants are sent for, why you'l loose your Dinner.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What do I hear? here's fine work indeed.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: What the Devil is to do there? is that Damn'd Jade my Lady dead?

sp.speaker: C. Fellow.
sp.p: Nay I know not, we shall hear when I go, the Bells ring, do you not hear 'em? and there's order given for all the Parishes hereabouts to ring, Barrels of Beer, Flaggons of Brandy and Money for the Ringers, and Alms to all the Poor are ordered.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Death what's this? Here's a rout when I am gone, did they pack me away for this, I shall have all my Estate run out.

sp.speaker: C. Fellow
sp.p: Come, come, make hast.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Husband, shan't I go with you?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Why, what all'st thou? Did not I tell thee I wou'd strap thee yesterday for desiring to go, art thou at it again?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What does this Villain mean by strapping, and yesterday?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: What a Pox, I have been married but six weeks, and you long to make me a Cuckold already, stay at home there's good cold Pye in the Cupboard. But I'll trust you no more with strong Beer Huzwife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, you will have your way, I must do what you bid me.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: That's a good Wench, God be with you, come on Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And I'll be there not long after you, sure I shall meet some there that are not of the Conspiracy.

div.stage: Scene Sir Richard's House, Sir Richard and all the Company at Dinner.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Son-in-Law Sir Richard I long to see Mr. Noddy, methinks I did not eat the meat with Appetite since he did not bless the Creature.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Sir to tell you the truth he is very sick, he was drunk last night, I am sorry to say it to you.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Son-in-Law, I know you are a Lukewarm Formalist of the Episcopal way, and you are glad to say it, but I believe it not.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir, I do not use to lye, the whole Family are witnesses of it.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: I fear me they are all too much of the same Batch, will my Daughter affirm this?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I must needs say what Sir Richard says.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, perhaps he might e're he was aware be overtaken with the Creature, he might be transported perhaps with Zeal and so the sooner overtaken, and so 'tis not a sin, but a frailty in him that is Righteous: I must see him.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: But 'tis a sin in us: very good Doctrine.
sp.l: Though Zeal stand Sentry at the Gate of Sin,
Yet all that have the Word pass freely In.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: I am sorry to see you ill Mr. Noddy.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Bless your Worship.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Now we have dined let him give Thanks.

div.stage: [Noddy is humming and haughing in order to his Grace.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Here's a Riot and a Rout, you sirrah, Butler, Rogue.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Why how now? what a Pox is to do with you? who are you?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Impudent Varlet! don't you know your Lady?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Why how now you Quean? here, turn this Madwoman out of Doors.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: S' Life you Rascal take that sirrah, why sirrah? don't you know your Lady? my Lady Lovemore, hands off, I am she you Rogue.

div.stage: She flings the Glass in his Face which he had in his hands, and Servingman lays hold on her.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Why you faucy Jade? Huzwife have a care here's a good pump, we'll cool your Courage for you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why Iane? Huzwife, sure you do not forget me?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Forget thee Woman! why? I never remembeed thee, I ne're saw thee in my Life.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh wicked Slut! I'll give thee cause to remember me.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Oh murder! murder! help, help!

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: How now, what Uproar's there?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You Jade, Lettice! what won't you know me neither? I'll make you know your Lady.

div.stage: [Lady strikes her, she breaks from her.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Help, help!

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: What's to do there?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Why? here's a Madwoman falls a beating and lugging us, and calls her self my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Some Christmas frolick, some Neighbour has a mind to be merry.

sp.speaker: Nell
sp.p: I warrant it is a Bess of Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh here's my Chaplain, sure he is not of the Conspiracy against me! Mr. Noddy! Thou art an holy man.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: I am so Woman, what would'st thou have with me?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What are you blind? do you not know me because I have these filthy Clothes on? look on my Face, I am the most injur'd, the most abused Lady that ever yet drew Breath.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Lady! Woman, art thou not mad in truth?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why sirrah, are not you my Chaplain? You base Villain, did not I lay on the Plaister to your shoulders, and a red hot Pan to your Head last Night, and sav'd your Life?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! this is the Sorceress that bewitch'd me this Night, lay hold on her she is a Witch.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Why Master Noddy? art not thou troubled in Spirit? it is surely a Trick, a Gambal.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Father here! I am so distracted with my grieff and sufferings I did not see you, but now I must embrace you, and never leave you till you succour and revenge me, for the most Barbarous usage that ever Lady suffer'd: speak, will you not speak to me, Honoured Father?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: I know thee not, I fear thou art some lewd woman; be gone, hands off.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay, then I am desperately miserable.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: She a is Witch and did confess it to me, I will have her burnt.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Stand by, there must be something more than ordinary in this Business.

sp.speaker: Longm.
sp.p: What the Devil can this mean?

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: What shou'd it mean? some poor Madwoman is got loose.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Why? I never saw thee, thou my Wife? poor Creature I pity thee.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay 'tis in vain to hope for Redress from thee, thou wicked Contriver of all my Misery.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: How I am amazed! is that I there in my Clothes, that have made this disturbance? oh Father! I am here in these fine Clothes, how can this be? and yet to my thinking I am there, I am so confounded and affrighted, that I shall begin to wish I were with Zekell Iobson again.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To whom shall I apply my self? or whither shall I flie? oh Heaven what do I see! Is not that I there in my Gown and Petticoat I wore yesterday? how can it be when I am here? I can not be in two places at once.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Surely no, unless thou wer't a Bird, but come Sir let's be deaf to these vile Gambals and retire.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Poor Creature she's stark mad.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What in the Devil's Name, was I here before I came hither? that I shou'd come hither, and find that I was here before I came is the strangest thing to me, let me look in this Glass, Oh Heaven I am confounded, I know not my self, if that be I that's represented in the Glass, I never saw my self before.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: What incoherent madness is this?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: pointing to Nell. There, there's the Devil in my likeness, that has robb'd me of my Countenance, S' Life is he here.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Ay that must be the Devil that's in your Likeness, remember my strap you Quean.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How inevitably wretched am I?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: O Lord, I am afraid my Husband will beat me that am on yonder side?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Gallants pray pardon her, she was drinking with a Conjurer last Night, and she has been mad ever since, and says she is my Lady Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Poor Woman take care of her, and do not hurt her, she may be cured of this.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Cured, yes and please your Worship, you shall see me cure her with this strap immediately, Huzwife do you see this?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Hold, hold, pray do not beat me Zekel.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: What says my Dear? Does she insect thee with madness too?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I am not well, my head turns round.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Wait on your Lady in.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: I beseech your Worship don't take it ill of me, she shall never trouble you more.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Take her home and use her kindly, I'll send my Physician to her shall cure her I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Thank your Worship most kindly, come Nell.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: How now, where's my Father-in-Law?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: He has taken Coach, he bid me tell you he loves no Christmas-Gambals, and he took this for one.

sp.speaker: Longm.
sp.p: It is a very odd one take it all together, as e're I saw?

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: Methought there was a Method in her madness, she did not know her self i'th Glass.

sp.speaker: Longm.
sp.p: And if you observed, your Lady uttered some strange words.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: She did so, which did very much amaze me.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: But that I have not much Belief in Magick, I shou'd have odd thoughts of this.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Now you have put me in mind of it, there was something in the latter part of this story, very strange and very surprizing.

sp.speaker: Serv. M.
sp.p: Sir, the Doctor who call'd here last Night, desires a word in private with you on earnest Business.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: What can this mean? bring him to me.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: We'll take a turn and wait on you suddenly.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Your servant Gentlemen, be gone Servants.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Low on my knees I fall, and beg your pardon, and put my Life into your hands, I have exercised my art of Magick on your Lady, I know you are an honourable Man, and will not take my Life, who might have still concealed it from you, if I had pleased.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Methinks you have brought me to a glimpse of misery, too great for me to bear, is all my happiness come only to a short Live'd Vision and a Dream?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Sir I beseech you fear not, if there be any harm towards you, I freely give you leave to hang me.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Can Magick bring me any thing but ill?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I never yet did mischief by my Art, there are Aerial Spirits I command which do no hurt, they are Sylphs.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: What have you done? inform me.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I have so transform'd your Ladie's face, she seems to be the Cobler's Wife, and charmed the face of Iobson's Wife into the Likeness of your Ladies, and when the storm arose, my Spirits removed each to the others Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Oh miserable wretch thou hast undone me, I am fallen from the top of all my hopes, and still must have a most tempestuous Wife, that fury whom I never yet knew quiet, since the first minute I had her.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: If that were all, I cou'd continue the Charm for both their Lives.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: I'll have no happiness from Hell, all my Blessings must come from Heaven, and I will hang you if you will not undo your Charm, let the event be what it will.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I'll do it in a moment, and perhaps you'l find it is the luckiest moment of your Life, I can well assure you your Lady will prove the best of Wives, give me your pardon Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Upon condition you undo the Charm I will.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: It shall be done, and you shall find all my Praediction true.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Hold there is yet a material thing, which I must know.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I will resolve you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: May be to Crown this mischief I have suffer'd, the Cobler may perhaps have made me Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Then cut this Throat, for e're she was transported to that Bed; the Cobler was got up, besides he has done nought but beat her ever since, and you are like to reap the benefit of his Labour.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Go about the business, i'll send for him and her.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I can assure you, there's no staying for you in this Family; my Lady has yielded all up to my Mistress's power.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Why look thee Edward Chip; thou art mistaken in me, I can conform in many things, rather than leave so good a House and so good People.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Where there is so much eating.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: At least though I cannot conform inwardly, I will conform outwardly; and that will do your business as well, give us some Wine, they shall see what I can do.

div.stage: Enter Servingman, Cook, and all the Servants.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: With all my heart, Gentlemen you are come in good time to be merry with Mr. Noddy.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Ay God I'm in a merry humour.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Here's a pretty turn.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Give me a Beer-glass, here's the King and all the Royal Family, Huzzah: to ' ther, here's Sir Richard Lovemore's, huzzah: the to'ther, nay Gad take me give me a third, here's my Ladies, huzzah: pledge me all of you, and let every Bumper be a facer thus.

div.stage: [They drink off their Glasses, and Huzzah.

sp.speaker: Servm.
sp.p: Is that a facer, faith t'is very pretty.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Nounz I'll have you to know, I can be as good Company as e're a he that wears a head.
sp.l: He that wears a brave Soul, and dares honestly do,
Hee's a Herald to himself and a Godfather too.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Here's a Transformation.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Come faith, let's sing a Catch.
sp.l: A Boat, a Boat, haste to the Ferry,
For we come over to be merry;
To laugh and Quaff, and drink old Sherry.

div.stage: Enter Sir Richard by the Door.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Here's a turn; here's a Hypocritical Rogue, I think we shall have Ovid's Metamorphosis in this House, but I am too much concern'd to mind this Diversion: but where are my Friends I wonder.

div.stage: Enter the Wassalers, and sing their Wassel Song.
[Noddy joyns with e'm in the Song.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Come on Friends, and fall heartily to our Christmas Gambals after a Rouze or two.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: What you tell us Sir has much of wonder in it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: It is prodigious if it prove true.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Come now, lets have a dance.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Now Parson let's have one Christmass-Gambal, we'll play the Black-smith.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Ay come with all my heart, how is that?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Come we'll show you, you shall down first, here, lye down upon this form.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Ay come, come, Gad I'm almost drunk.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Come I'll play the Smith and blow the Bellows, ye are my two Journey-men.

div.stage: They beat upon him like two Smiths with Boots, he roars out Murder, Murder, all the Company laugh, and they leave off when Sir Richard speaks.

sp.speaker: Cook. Serv. m.
sp.p: We are ready.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Be sure you lay him on.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: How now Iobson, have you brought your Wife with you?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Yes and please your Worship, she's here at the Door, a little from the House she fell into a Swoon'd, I thought I ne're shou'd have recovered her. But at last a tweak or two by the Nose, and half a Dozen straps has done the Business, here where are you Huswife, come in?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Light there 'tis very dark.

div.stage: [He lets fall the Candle and Servingman takes it up.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: O Heaven and Earth, what's this my Lady?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: What does he say, is my Wife chang'd to my Lady?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I thought the other was too good to be my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: to Sir Richard. You are the Person I have most offended to whom I must confess I have been the worst of Women, bating I have kept my Body undefiled, it has pleased Heaven to punish me most sharply for my Crimes, Heaven left me to suffer under the power of Enchantment, I am fully sensible of all my faults, and since I abhor 'em and detest my self for them, I hope that Heaven and you will pardon me, here will I kneel and fix till I have procur'd yours at least, and Heaven be witness to my Resolutions. The Remnant of my Life shall be imploy'd in duty and observance of you, if you'l vouchsafe to take me to your Bosom.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Rise Madam I forgive you, and if you be sincere, you'l make me happier than all the Enjoyments of the world could do.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: What a pox must I lose my Wife thus? where the Devil is my to'ther wife? here's conjuring indeed.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Oh Sir the strangest accident has happened, it has amazed us, and almost bereft us of our sences, my Lady was in so great a swound we thought she had been dead.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: And when she came to her self, she proved another woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Ha, ha, that's a Bull indeed.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: She is so chang'd I know her not, I never saw her face before, O Lord is this my Lady!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I shall be beaten again.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: I thought our happiness was too great to last.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Fear not my Servants, Sir let 'em all be call'd in, I will give ease and quiet to your Family, I am a hearty Penitent, good Servants I acknowledge I have All the Servants and Teunants come in. been too harsh and rigorous to ye all, but Heaven has given me another mind, it shall be my endeavour to make ye all happy. I'm sure no Mistress shall outdoe me in Kindness and in Gentleness.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Hold in this mind, thou wilt be the best of women, and I the happiest of men, the other was false and short liv'd Joy, but this I hope will long continue.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: May Heaven wreak all its vengeance on me if once I alter from this Resolution, or e're I contradict your will again.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: This is a day of wonders.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: My head turns round I must go home, why Zekel what are you there?

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: Look you, look you now, hey day, what a Devil, what's that Queen my wife? here's a rare business, Gad I dare not come near her.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: 'Tis rare indeed, we have all this day been under the Power of Enchantment, to which Heaven knows there was not my least Consent. Heaven often turns even the malice of Devils to produce a good end, this is no doubt a happy change, I'll celebrate it with all the joy I did proclaim, for my late short liv'd Vision.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To me 'tis happier than my Birth-day was.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Now Madam since you have resign'd your will to me, where is the Chaplain?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Here Mr. Noddy where are you? he's in the Buttery, here come in.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Behold your saint here.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I do confess my self in the wrong.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Go Hypocrite, I discard thee.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Discard me for what, Nounz I'll conform, what a Pox do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Thou wicked Wretch, thou scandal to thy own Profession, woud'st thou maliciously thus bring one on ours, by thinking to conform by being vicious? detested Beast be gone, carry him to his Chamber, our Church condemns all such Debauchery, though such vile wretches wou'd bring a scandal on it. Give him ten Pound, and in the Morning send him packing: here Iobson take they fine wife.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: But hold Sir, did not your Worship Sir make me a Cuckold under the Rose?

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: No upon my honour nor ever kist her till I came from hunting, she was my Bedfellow for a little while, and for this happy change, I'll give thee with her five hundred Pound, buy store of Lether, and be my Shoemaker, I'll help thee to all the Custome in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Iobson.
sp.p: He boys I am a Prince, a Prince, come hither Nell, come to thine own dear Zekel, I'll never strap thee more.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Indeed I have been in such a dream, I'm quite weary of it.

sp.speaker: Iobson kneels.
sp.p: Can your good Ladyship forgive my strapping your good Ladyship so very much.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With all my heart, the joy of this blest change makes all things good again.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: Forsooth Madam will you please to take your Clothes, and let me have mine again.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No thou shalt keep 'em, and I'll preserve thine as Reliques.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Gentlemen let me present you to my Wife.

sp.speaker: Rowl.
sp.p: We wish your Ladyship all the joy your heart can hope for.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: May all your Life be ever happy Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Gentlemen pray pardon me, and I think I was a Madwoman last night, Heaven now has brought me to my self.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: No more of this Subject.
sp.l: Proclaim my joys in every place aloud,
Bonfires surround my house, let the Bells ring,
Let's dance and revel, feast, carouze and sing.

sp.speaker: All the Servants cry.
sp.p: Long live my Lady and Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Jobson.
sp.l: Now let me speak if I may be so bold,
Nought but the Devil sure can tame a Scold.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE,
div.stage: Spoken by Mr. Jevon, and Mrs. Percyval.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ievon.
sp.p: COme Nell, prithee while I dress for the Dance speak something in my behalf to these Friends of mine here, for I'm sure they are all Friends.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Percyval.
sp.p: Who I Zekel? Oh Lord you know, I wand dacity when I come before great Folks.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ievon.
sp.p: How now Huzwife dare you dispute it? remember my strap you Quean.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Percyval.
sp.p: Hold, hold good Husband, I'll try what I can do?

sp.speaker: To the People.
sp.p: Oh most curious fine Gentlefolks, I hope you will pardon me for being so bold, but ne're stir, I'll never let you alone till I find you kind to poor Zekel, for he's as pretty a Fellow as e're strapp'd Wife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ievon.
sp.p: Why how now, what a Pox is all this for? what speak an Epilogue in Prose? (the Devil) I cou'd have done that my self you foolish Jade. For example now,
sp.stage: Addresses himself to the Audience, and makes a long Banter, and goes off, after that he speaks.
sp.p: Look you Huzwife, there's as good Prose as any is in England, but I must have it in Verse, all beaten Verse, away with it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Percyval.
sp.l: YOV cannot sure ungenerously refuse,
The first address of a young tender muse;
So modest that she ne're attempts to fly,
Vp to the lofty pitch of Comedy:
Farce is her aim, the persons low and mean,
Humble the language homely it the seene.
Let this poor shrub secure from censure grow,
For all the Critiques stormy rage too low:
If you'l your thundering indignation vent,
Let it on lofty bumbast all be spent.
Applauded nonsence where sad lovers pine,
And Hero's rant and fight and cry and whine;
And the old buskins empty swelling strains,
That cracks the Player's lungs and Poet's brains.
These, these are triumphs for your forces fit,
But who upon a Droll e're spent his wit;
Or crititiz'd on Merry Andrew yet?
Whilst all the lofty Frigots you attacque,
Pray let in safety pass this little smack.
Your shot 'gainst us will wast 'ith empty sky,
The whistling bullets o're our heads will flye;
We lye so low your Canon mount too high.
